Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Rhomboids from Streptomyces: The Unknown Key Player?

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Streptomyces are soil bacteria that produce natural products that serve many functions for the bacteria and also possess a number of interesting and useful properties that include anti-bacterial, anti-tumor and anti-parasitic properties. Interactions between Streptomyces and the environment regulate the synthesis of these natural products but much remains unknown about this process. This project addresses the role of rhomboids, a family of protein-degrading enzymes, in the communication of Streptomyces with the environment and is anticipated to shed light on how bacteria "talk" to each other and sense a changing environment. Student research opportunities from this project will be incorporated into the courses that are taught. Students (including members of underrepresented groups) will conduct genetic, molecular and microbiological research and their work will be presented at State, regional and national conferences; they will have opportunities to author publications on their research. In addition a Science, Technology and Engineering Program (STEP) program will engage high school students interested in research, and Queensborough Community College undergraduates will help to mentor them.

The objective of this project is to determine the role of rhomboids in Streptomyces coelicolor. Putative rhomboid genes identified through bioinformatics analysis will be knocked-out and the developmental cycle and the production of secondary metabolites will be compared in wild-type and gene knock-out bacterial strains. Mutant rescue studies will be used to characterize the function of rhomboid genes from diverse Streptomyces species and to investigate their role in regulating cell signaling, thereby providing insights into the molecular evolution of regulatory mechanisms in bacteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Streptomyces are soil bacteria that produce natural products with multiple functions for the bacteria. Natural products also possess a number of interesting and useful properties that include anti-bacterial, anti-tumor and anti-inflammatory properties. How the interactions between Streptomyces and the environment regulate the synthesis of these natural products is only partially understood today. Our project addressed the role of rhomboids, a family of protein-degrading enzymes, in the communication of Streptomyces with the environment. Through this project, we have found that rhomboids are involved in the transport of secreted proteins. The most conserved of the putative rhomboid genes identified through bioinformatics analysis was knocked-out and the developmental cycle and the production of secondary metabolites was compared in wild-type and gene knock-out bacterial strain. The knock out mutant showed impairment in a transport system that exists in bacteria and plants, the twin arginine translocon system. This transport system is responsible of secreting many signaling molecules confirming our hypothesis that rhomboids are involved in the communication of Streptomyces with their environment.

Several Queensborough Community College (QCC) students have participated in this research, not just acquiring new laboratory skills and being immersed in scientific methodology, but also taking ownership of their projects and learning to work independently. These students have presented at regional and national conferences, proudly winning awards and fellowships. One of them had his research paper accepted to the Columbia Undergraduate Science Journal that will be published this fall. All of these students have successfully transferred to four year colleges. One student that participated in the project at QCC is now beginning a PhD program at UPenn. Aspects of this project were incorporated into courses at QCC, such as Environmental Science and General Microbiology. Additionally, through a QCC Science, Technology and Engineering Program (STEP) program has engaged high school students.
